ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to debate and look at ideas from a philosophical and tangible perspective.
This class was based on the workings of our government and comparing it to other possible models of government.

I learned so much about how we can reform democracy in America. The course made me consider what democratic institutions outside of government look like, as well as how those can be improved. I feel that I also got much better as a writer from the course as well.
I learned so much about Participatory Democracy. It was a great look into the theories and practices of Participatory Democracy, and I walked away with even more questions than I started with.
I delved into the fundamental texts of participatory democrats and learned how to put different authors in conversation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: prof and interesting concepts. Super engaging.
NO weaknesses, take any class that you can with Fairdosi.
The biggest strength of this course was the discussion session, where we were able to share ideas and Professor Fairdosi was able to break down the topics with us.

Strengths: Professor Fairdosi is a gem. He is an incredibly gifted teacher, and it is impossible not to leave class each week without completely understanding the issues that were discussed. His ability to communicate complex information in a digestible manner is commendable. He also is great at ensuring a fair workload, and giving feedback. It was impossible to leave class without a smile. Also his ability to facilitate discussion brings out the best in all of his students. The class is structured in a way that forces you to really engage and critically think about the theories that are being discussed, and the workload is manageable. It is impossible to not feel like an expert leaving the class. 

Weaknesses: none, all Yale students should take a class with Professor Fairdosi

Strength: Professor Fairdosi is a huge strength of this course. His lectures at the beginning of the class set up each discussion and provided extra background, clarifying the readings for the week. The questions he raised were thought-provoking, and the class size (only 7 people!) made for a refreshing classroom environment, facilitating learning from each other. Weaknesses: There were no weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: ABSOLUTELY, this was my favorite class this semester. This is my second class with Professor Fairdosi and I want to take more with him in the future. He's engaging, chooses interesting topics, and makes sure that we are in an environment where nothing is off the table and we were in a safe space.
Yes, it is highly engaging and I came away with a lot more knowledge of the government than I had going in.

100% even non Political science students should take a class with Professor Fairdosi. He is a phenomenal teacher, and the course is designed in a way that forces you to engage and learn so much (without causing burnout). I learned so much about representative democracy, and really saw my thoughts evolve over the semester. Also his ability to facilitate discussion brings out the best in all of his students.
If you can get in and have any interest in participatory democracy, yes!!! It's a great higher level seminarwould especially recommend as a junior or senior.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in a preliminary analysis of participatory forms of democracy. Also, students with a love for United States history will enjoy this course; readings and discussions provide insight into why the United States relies on a representative system for governance and in so doing limits the ability of average citizens to possess political influence.
